territory.notes: Although the Treaty of Paris in 1814 recognized French sovereignty over the area that is now Mauritania, France only briefly exercised actual jurisdiction and control over portions of the region in the mid-19th century, and did not consistently do so until the beginning of the 20th century. Accordingly, various Maure groups and emirates (Trarza, Brakna, Tagant, Adrar), some of which engaged in treaties with the French, effectively continued to maintain sovereignty or suzerainty in the region throughout much of this period. The French colonial administration based in Senegal sporadically came into conflict with the Emirates of Trarza and Brakna throughout the 19th century, particularly in 1825 and 1855, resulting in intermittent periods of French control over portions of what is now Mauritania. By treaty following a French military victory in 1856, the Emirates of Trarza and Brakna conceded a French protectorate over their emirates and acknowledged French sovereignty over the northern bank of the Senegal River. French officials subsequently surveyed portions of western and southern Mauritania, including Adrar. By the 1870’s, however, the French no longer exerted active control or governance over present-day Mauritania. In 1901, French officials began an active effort to “peacefully” assert sovereignty throughout what is now Mauritania. Brakna came under French control in February 1904.
